title: Metal Bar on Rails mathematical reasoning

content.question: (a) i. On the axes in Figure 2, sketch a graph of the current <math alttext="I" overflow="scroll"> <mi>I</mi> </math> induced in the circuit as a function of the component of the velocity of the bar parallel to the incline. Your sketch should include positive and negative values of <math alttext="v" overflow="scroll"><mi>v</mi></math>.

frqParts.text: (a) i. On the axes in Figure 2, sketch a graph of the current <math alttext="I" overflow="scroll"> <mi>I</mi> </math> induced in the circuit as a function of the component of the velocity of the bar parallel to the incline. Your sketch should include positive and negative values of <math alttext="v" overflow="scroll"><mi>v</mi></math>.

ii. Derive an expression for the net force <math alttext="F sub net" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mtext>net</mtext></msub></math> exerted on the bar when the bar is moving with a nonzero speed down the rails. Express your answer in terms of <math alttext="M" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>M</mi></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="theta" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>θ</mi></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>B</mi></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>D</mi></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>R</mi></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="v" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>v</mi></mstyle></math>, and physical constants, as appropriate. Begin your derivation by writing a fundamental physics principle or an equation from the reference booklet.

(b) The rails are repositioned to be horizontal, as shown in Figure <math alttext="3" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math>, with the magnetic field still perpendicular to the plane formed by the rails. The bar is then given an initial velocity <math alttext="v sub 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mstyle></math> in the positive direction, which is now toward the right. i. Using the expression for <math alttext="F sub net" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mtext>net</mtext></msub></math> from part (a)(ii), derive, but do NOT solve, a differential equation for the bar’s velocity <math alttext="v" overflow="scroll"><mi>v</mi></math> when the rails are horizontal. Express your equation in terms of \(v_0\) and time <math alttext="t" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi></math>, as well as <math alttext="M" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>M</mi></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="theta" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>θ</mi></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>B</mi></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>D</mi></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>R</mi></mstyle></math>, and physical constants, as appropriate. Begin your derivation by writing a fundamental physics principle or an equation from the reference booklet.

ii. Solve the differential equation from part (b)(i) to derive an expression for the speed <math alttext="v" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>v</mi></math> of the bar as a function of time <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi></math>.

skill.text: 1.C: Create qualitative sketches of graphs that represent features of a model or the behavior of a physical system.
